body.p:
Elkton Ky. May 25th 1865
His Excellency
Thos E Bramlett

The undersigned citizens of Todd County Kentucky State that at the April Term 1862 of the Todd Circuit Court the Grand Jury of said County returned into said Court an indictment against against William A Dowdy, J H Millen, Georg Harrel, and Al Tolbert Jr. charging them with the crime of robbery in taking from Wm B Downey several Sacks of sugar. and a pistol.

At the time the offence is charged to have been committed. the parties accused were confederate soldiers in a camp near Allensville Ky. and were recruited. and commanded by a man called Col Hornsby They had complete Military possession of this county. William B Downy started. from Elkton. towards Greenville with several sacks of Sugar and when six or eight miles from Elkton in the direction of Green river he was over taken by a squad of Rebel Soldiers in command of George. Harrel who was first Lieutant. and the sugar was seized & taken through Elkton and as we were informed to the camp at Allensville where it was used by Col. Hornsby's command. The pistol was returned to Downey, and after the rebel soldiers left Wm C Harrel (the father of George Harrel) who is a very worthy clever farmer of this county paid Downey full price for all the sugar We are well satisfied the sugar was taken by a direct order from Col Hornsby. Some twelve months after Hornsby left Leut. Harrell resigned, came home took
the oath of allegiance conducted himself as a good citizen, and remained with for some time then went to Canada to ^avoid^ arrest and trial under said indictment, where he now is
Young Harrel both before, and after his enlistment in the army sustained the character of an upright honorable young man Now stood better
His father promptly paid for every thing taken in this neighborhood when he was along and he left because he feared the prejudices against his associates might cause his conviction

We have full confidence that George Harrel if allowed to return will make a worthy moral & valuable member of society -- and if consistent with your views of duty and property We respectfully ask the interposition of Executive Clemency in granting to sd George Harrell a pardon for the offence charged or such other relief as may seem just and proper to Your Excellency

W A Glenn
G Wallace. Gatte
H. G Petree
S H Perkins
J. G. Hollingworth
S Crabb
G. B. Lewis
J W. Lewis
E. R. Price
S W Kennedy
S. H. Grooms
H. G. Bibb
Jesse Russell
W H Roberts
J O M Ghee

Can't pardon any one who has fled from custody --
Refused
